Text given to you is Angie Mentink (born October 18, 1972) is the co-anchor of Mariners Live. Mentink joined FSN in 1998, reporting on the Seattle Mariners and Seattle Seahawks for FSN Northwest. Prior to entering the broadcast profession, Mentink was a three-time college All-America softball player at the University of Washington and later played professional baseball as an original member of the Colorado Silver Bullets. <s>[INST] You are a helpful agent that derives knowledge graph from the english text provided by the user. Entities you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: The exchange in chess, player, minor piece, bishop, knight, opponent's rook, side, exchange, rook. Relationships you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: loses, captures, wins, said to have won, has lost, is up, is down, opposing captures. Objects you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: situation, bishop or knight, rook, valuable, consecutive moves. Text given to you is The exchange in chess refers to a situation in which one player loses a minor piece (i.e. a bishop or knight) but captures the opponent's rook. The side which wins the rook is said to have won the exchange, while the other player has lost the exchange, since the rook is usually more valuable. Subsequently, the side that has won the rook is up the exchange, and the other player is down the exchange. The opposing captures often happen on consecutive moves, although this is not strictly necessary. [/INST], <http://dbpedia.org/resource/The_exchange_%28chess%29> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> "The exchange in chess refers to a situation in which one player loses a minor piece (i.e. a bishop or knight) but captures the opponent's rook.".
<http://dbpedia.org/resource/The_exchange_%28chess%29> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> "The side which wins the rook is said to have won the exchange, while the other player has lost the exchange, since the rook is usually more valuable.".
<http://dbpedia.org/resource/The_exchange_%28chess%29> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> "Subsequently, the side that has won the rook is up the exchange, and the other player is down the exchange.".
<http://dbpedia.org/resource/The_exchange_%28chess%29> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> "The opposing captures often happen on consecutive moves, although this is not strictly necessary.". </s>

Entities you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: Rainulf Drengot, Norman adventurer, count of Aversa, Osmond, Richard I of Normandy, murder, kin, Gilbert Buat�re, Asclettin, Raulf, pilgrimage, soldier-archangel, Michael, Monte Sant'Angelo sul Gargano, Byzantine Catepanate of Italy, band of 250 warriors, exiles, landless cadets, adventurers, Mezzogiorno, state of virtual anarchy, stronghold, Monte Gargano, Apulia, Lombard Melus, Bari, Byzantine overlords. Relationships you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: was, adventurer, count of, exiled by, murder of, went on, pilgrimage to, shrine of, soldier-archangel, at, rebelled against, but who was currently on the run, arrived in, was in a state of, Establishing a stronghold at, joined forces with. Objects you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: Rainulf Drengot, Norman adventurer, count of Aversa, Osmond, Richard I of Normandy, murder, kin, Gilbert Buat�re, Asclettin, Raulf, pilgrimage, soldier-archangel, Michael, Monte Sant'Angelo sul Gargano, Byzantine Catepanate of Italy, band of 250 warriors, exiles, landless cadets, adventurers, Mezzogiorno, state of virtual anarchy, stronghold, Monte Gargano, Apulia, Lombard Melus, Bari, Byzantine overlords. Text given to you is Rainulf Drengot (also Ranulph, Ranulf, or Rannulf) was a Norman adventurer and the first count of Aversa . When one of Rainulf's numerous brothers, Osmond, was exiled by Richard I of Normandy for the murder of one of his kin, Rainulf, Osmond, and their brothers Gilbert Buat�re, Asclettin, and Raulf went on a pilgrimage to the shrine of the soldier-archangel, Michael, at Monte Sant'Angelo sul Gargano in the Byzantine Catepanate of Italy. They brought with them a band of 250 warriors, formed of other exiles, landless cadets and similar adventurers. In 1017 they arrived in the Mezzogiorno, which was in a state of virtual anarchy. Establishing a stronghold at Monte Gargano in Apulia, they joined forces with the Lombard Melus of Bari, who had rebelled against his Byzantine overlords but who was currently on the run. [/INST], <http://dbpedia.org/resource/Rainulf_Drengot> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> "Rainulf Drengot (also Ranulph, Ranulf, or Rannulf) was a Norman adventurer and the first count of Aversa . When one of Rainulf's numerous brothers, Osmond, was exiled by Richard I of Normandy for the murder of one of his kin, Rainulf, Osmond, and their brothers Gilbert Buat�re, Asclettin, and Raulf went on a pilgrimage to the shrine of the soldier-archangel, Michael, at Monte Sant'Angelo sul Gargano in the Byzantine Catepanate of Italy. They brought with them a band of 250 warriors, formed of other exiles, landless cadets and similar adventurers. In 1017 they arrived in the Mezzogiorno, which was in a state of virtual anarchy. Establishing a stronghold at Monte Gargano in Apulia, they joined forces with the Lombard Melus of Bari, who had rebelled against his Byzantine overlords but who was currently on the run." </s>

<s>[INST] You are a helpful agent that derives knowledge graph from the english text provided by the user. Entities you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: Bigeminy, heart arrhythmia, abnormal heart beats, concurrent beat, bigeminal premature ventricular beats, premature ventricular contractions/complexes, PVC, pause, normal beat. Relationships you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: descriptor for, occur every other, known as, Following, returns, followed by, continuation of. Objects you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: heart arrhythmia, abnormal heart beats, concurrent beat, bigeminal premature ventricular beats, premature ventricular contractions/complexes, PVC, pause, normal beat, pairing of beats, bigeminy. Text given to you is Bigeminy is a descriptor for a heart arrhythmia in which abnormal heart beats occur every other concurrent beat. A typical example is with bigeminal premature ventricular beats, also known as a premature ventricular contractions/complexes . Following the PVC there is a pause and then the normal beat returns - only to be followed by another PVC. The continuation of this pairing of beats is an example of bigeminy. [/INST], <http://dbpedia.org/resource/Bigeminy> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> 'Bigeminy is a descriptor for a heart arrhythmia in which abnormal heart beats occur every other concurrent beat. A typical example is with bigeminal premature ventricular beats, also known as a premature ventricular contractions/complexes . Following the PVC there is a pause and then the normal beat returns - only to be followed by another PVC. The continuation of this pairing of beats is an example of bigeminy.'. </s>

<s>[INST] You are a helpful agent that derives knowledge graph from the english text provided by the user. Entities you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: Twelve-step program, guiding principles, recovery, addiction, compulsion, behavioral problems, Alcoholics Anonymous (AA), method, alcoholism, Twelve Steps, book, Alcoholics Anonymous, 1939, foundation, Narcotics Anonymous, Overeaters Anonymous, Co-Dependents Anonymous, Debtors Anonymous, process, twelve-step recovery, Dr. Bob. Relationships you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: proposed by, method of recovery from, first published in, adapted and became the foundation of, characterized by. Objects you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: set of guiding principles, recovery from addiction, compulsion, or other behavioral problems, recovery from alcoholism, other twelve-step programs, Trust God, clean house, help others. Text given to you is A twelve-step program is a set of guiding principles for recovery from addiction, compulsion, or other behavioral problems. Originally proposed by Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) as a method of recovery from alcoholism, the Twelve Steps were first published in the book, Alcoholics Anonymous in 1939. The method was then adapted and became the foundation of other twelve-step programs such as Narcotics Anonymous, Overeaters Anonymous, Co-Dependents Anonymous and Debtors Anonymous. The process of twelve-step recovery has been characterized by Dr. Bob - one of AA's co-founders - as "Trust God, clean house, help others". [/INST], <http://dbpedia.org/resource/Twelve-step_program> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> "A twelve-step program is a set of guiding principles for recovery from addiction, compulsion, or other behavioral problems. Originally proposed by Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) as a method of recovery from alcoholism, the Twelve Steps were first published in the book, Alcoholics Anonymous in 1939. The method was then adapted and became the foundation of other twelve-step programs such as Narcotics Anonymous, Overeaters Anonymous, Co-Dependents Anonymous and Debtors Anonymous. The process of twelve-step recovery has been characterized by Dr. Bob - one of AA's co-founders - as \"Trust God, clean house, help others\"." </s>

<s>[INST] You are a helpful agent that derives knowledge graph from the english text provided by the user. Objects you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: A Bioscope show, a fairground attraction, a travelling cinema, the late 1890s, World War I, the largest fairground organs, a stage, dancing girls, the crowds, film shows. Text given to you is A Bioscope show was a fairground attraction consisting of a travelling cinema. The heyday of the Bioscope was from the late 1890s until World War I. Bioscope shows were fronted by the largest fairground organs, and these formed the entire public face of the show . A stage was usually in front of the organ, and dancing girls would entertain the crowds between film shows. [/INST], <http://dbpedia.org/resource/Bioscope_show> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> 'A Bioscope show was a fairground attraction consisting of a travelling cinema. The heyday of the Bioscope was from the late 1890s until World War I. Bioscope shows were fronted by the largest fairground organs, and these formed the entire public face of the show . A stage was usually in front of the organ, and dancing girls would entertain the crowds between film shows.'. </s>

Objects you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: business simulation computer game, tycoon game, player, zoo, profit, expansion packs, sequel. Text given to you is Zoo Tycoon is an business simulation computer game developed by Blue Fang Games and released by Microsoft Game Studios. It is a tycoon game in which the player must run a zoo, and try to make a profit. Although first released for Microsoft Windows and Macintosh in 2001, it was ported to the Nintendo DS in 2005. It was followed by two expansion packs, Zoo Tycoon: Dinosaur Digs and Zoo Tycoon: Marine Mania, which were released in 2002, as well as a sequel, Zoo Tycoon 2, released in 2004. [/INST], <http://dbpedia.org/resource/Zoo_Tycoon> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> "Zoo Tycoon is an business simulation computer game developed by Blue Fang Games and released by Microsoft Game Studios. It is a tycoon game in which the player must run a zoo, and try to make a profit. Although first released for Microsoft Windows and Macintosh in 2001, it was ported to the Nintendo DS in 2005. It was followed by two expansion packs, Zoo Tycoon: Dinosaur Digs and Zoo Tycoon: Marine Mania, which were released in 2002, as well as a sequel, Zoo Tycoon 2, released in 2004.".

<s>[INST] You are a helpful agent that derives knowledge graph from the english text provided by the user. Entities you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: The exchange in chess, player, minor piece, bishop, knight, opponent's rook, side, exchange, rook. Relationships you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: loses, captures, wins, said to have won, has lost, is up, is down, opposing captures. Objects you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: situation, bishop or knight, rook, valuable, consecutive moves. Text given to you is The exchange in chess refers to a situation in which one player loses a minor piece (i.e. a bishop or knight) but captures the opponent's rook. The side which wins the rook is said to have won the exchange, while the other player has lost the exchange, since the rook is usually more valuable. Subsequently, the side that has won the rook is up the exchange, and the other player is down the exchange. The opposing captures often happen on consecutive moves, although this is not strictly necessary. [/INST], <http://dbpedia.org/resource/The_exchange_%28chess%29> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> "The exchange in chess refers to a situation in which one player loses a minor piece (i.e. a bishop or knight) but captures the opponent's rook.".
<http://dbpedia.org/resource/The_exchange_%28chess%29> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> "The side which wins the rook is said to have won the exchange, while the other player has lost the exchange, since the rook is usually more valuable.".
<http://dbpedia.org/resource/The_exchange_%28chess%29> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> "Subsequently, the side that has won the rook is up the exchange, and the other player is down the exchange.".
<http://dbpedia.org/resource/The_exchange_%28chess%29> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> "The opposing captures often happen on consecutive moves, although this is not strictly necessary.". </s>

Entities you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: Rainulf Drengot, Norman adventurer, count of Aversa, Osmond, Richard I of Normandy, murder, kin, Gilbert Buatère, Asclettin, Raulf, pilgrimage, soldier-archangel, Michael, Monte Sant'Angelo sul Gargano, Byzantine Catepanate of Italy, band of 250 warriors, exiles, landless cadets, adventurers, Mezzogiorno, state of virtual anarchy, stronghold, Monte Gargano, Apulia, Lombard Melus, Bari, Byzantine overlords. Relationships you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: was, adventurer, count of, exiled by, murder of, went on, pilgrimage to, shrine of, soldier-archangel, at, rebelled against, but who was currently on the run, arrived in, was in a state of, Establishing a stronghold at, joined forces with. Objects you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: Rainulf Drengot, Norman adventurer, count of Aversa, Osmond, Richard I of Normandy, murder, kin, Gilbert Buatère, Asclettin, Raulf, pilgrimage, soldier-archangel, Michael, Monte Sant'Angelo sul Gargano, Byzantine Catepanate of Italy, band of 250 warriors, exiles, landless cadets, adventurers, Mezzogiorno, state of virtual anarchy, stronghold, Monte Gargano, Apulia, Lombard Melus, Bari, Byzantine overlords. Text given to you is Rainulf Drengot (also Ranulph, Ranulf, or Rannulf) was a Norman adventurer and the first count of Aversa . When one of Rainulf's numerous brothers, Osmond, was exiled by Richard I of Normandy for the murder of one of his kin, Rainulf, Osmond, and their brothers Gilbert Buatère, Asclettin, and Raulf went on a pilgrimage to the shrine of the soldier-archangel, Michael, at Monte Sant'Angelo sul Gargano in the Byzantine Catepanate of Italy. They brought with them a band of 250 warriors, formed of other exiles, landless cadets and similar adventurers. In 1017 they arrived in the Mezzogiorno, which was in a state of virtual anarchy. Establishing a stronghold at Monte Gargano in Apulia, they joined forces with the Lombard Melus of Bari, who had rebelled against his Byzantine overlords but who was currently on the run. [/INST], <http://dbpedia.org/resource/Rainulf_Drengot> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> "Rainulf Drengot (also Ranulph, Ranulf, or Rannulf) was a Norman adventurer and the first count of Aversa . When one of Rainulf's numerous brothers, Osmond, was exiled by Richard I of Normandy for the murder of one of his kin, Rainulf, Osmond, and their brothers Gilbert Buatère, Asclettin, and Raulf went on a pilgrimage to the shrine of the soldier-archangel, Michael, at Monte Sant'Angelo sul Gargano in the Byzantine Catepanate of Italy. They brought with them a band of 250 warriors, formed of other exiles, landless cadets and similar adventurers. In 1017 they arrived in the Mezzogiorno, which was in a state of virtual anarchy. Establishing a stronghold at Monte Gargano in Apulia, they joined forces with the Lombard Melus of Bari, who had rebelled against his Byzantine overlords but who was currently on the run." </s>

<s>[INST] You are a helpful agent that derives knowledge graph from the english text provided by the user. Entities you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: Bigeminy, heart arrhythmia, abnormal heart beats, concurrent beat, bigeminal premature ventricular beats, premature ventricular contractions/complexes, PVC, pause, normal beat. Relationships you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: descriptor for, occur every other, known as, Following, returns, followed by, continuation of. Objects you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: heart arrhythmia, abnormal heart beats, concurrent beat, bigeminal premature ventricular beats, premature ventricular contractions/complexes, PVC, pause, normal beat, pairing of beats, bigeminy. Text given to you is Bigeminy is a descriptor for a heart arrhythmia in which abnormal heart beats occur every other concurrent beat. A typical example is with bigeminal premature ventricular beats, also known as a premature ventricular contractions/complexes . Following the PVC there is a pause and then the normal beat returns - only to be followed by another PVC. The continuation of this pairing of beats is an example of bigeminy. [/INST], <http://dbpedia.org/resource/Bigeminy> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> 'Bigeminy is a descriptor for a heart arrhythmia in which abnormal heart beats occur every other concurrent beat. A typical example is with bigeminal premature ventricular beats, also known as a premature ventricular contractions/complexes . Following the PVC there is a pause and then the normal beat returns - only to be followed by another PVC. The continuation of this pairing of beats is an example of bigeminy.'. </s>

<s>[INST] You are a helpful agent that derives knowledge graph from the english text provided by the user. Entities you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: Twelve-step program, guiding principles, recovery, addiction, compulsion, behavioral problems, Alcoholics Anonymous (AA), method, alcoholism, Twelve Steps, book, Alcoholics Anonymous, 1939, foundation, Narcotics Anonymous, Overeaters Anonymous, Co-Dependents Anonymous, Debtors Anonymous, process, twelve-step recovery, Dr. Bob. Relationships you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: proposed by, method of recovery from, first published in, adapted and became the foundation of, characterized by. Objects you'll be coming up with while generating knowledge graph from user-provided text are: set of guiding principles, recovery from addiction, compulsion, or other behavioral problems, recovery from alcoholism, other twelve-step programs, Trust God, clean house, help others. Text given to you is A twelve-step program is a set of guiding principles for recovery from addiction, compulsion, or other behavioral problems. Originally proposed by Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) as a method of recovery from alcoholism, the Twelve Steps were first published in the book, Alcoholics Anonymous in 1939. The method was then adapted and became the foundation of other twelve-step programs such as Narcotics Anonymous, Overeaters Anonymous, Co-Dependents Anonymous and Debtors Anonymous. The process of twelve-step recovery has been characterized by Dr. Bob - one of AA's co-founders - as "Trust God, clean house, help others". [/INST], <http://dbpedia.org/resource/Twelve-step_program> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> "A twelve-step program is a set of guiding principles for recovery from addiction, compulsion, or other behavioral problems. Originally proposed by Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) as a method of recovery from alcoholism, the Twelve Steps were first published in the book, Alcoholics Anonymous in 1939. The method was then adapted and became the foundation of other twelve-step programs such as Narcotics Anonymous, Overeaters Anonymous, Co-Dependents Anonymous and Debtors Anonymous. The process of twelve-step recovery has been characterized by Dr. Bob - one of AA's co-founders - as \"Trust God, clean house, help others\"." </s>

Text given to you is A Bioscope show was a fairground attraction consisting of a travelling cinema. The heyday of the Bioscope was from the late 1890s until World War I. Bioscope shows were fronted by the largest fairground organs, and these formed the entire public face of the show . A stage was usually in front of the organ, and dancing girls would entertain the crowds between film shows. [/INST], <http://dbpedia.org/resource/Bioscope_show> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> 'A Bioscope show was a fairground attraction consisting of a travelling cinema. The heyday of the Bioscope was from the late 1890s until World War I. Bioscope shows were fronted by the largest fairground organs, and these formed the entire public face of the show . A stage was usually in front of the organ, and dancing girls would entertain the crowds between film shows.'. </s>

Text given to you is Zoo Tycoon is an business simulation computer game developed by Blue Fang Games and released by Microsoft Game Studios. It is a tycoon game in which the player must run a zoo, and try to make a profit. Although first released for Microsoft Windows and Macintosh in 2001, it was ported to the Nintendo DS in 2005. It was followed by two expansion packs, Zoo Tycoon: Dinosaur Digs and Zoo Tycoon: Marine Mania, which were released in 2002, as well as a sequel, Zoo Tycoon 2, released in 2004. [/INST], <http://dbpedia.org/resource/Zoo_Tycoon> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment> "Zoo Tycoon is an business simulation computer game developed by Blue Fang Games and released by Microsoft Game Studios. It is a tycoon game in which the player must run a zoo, and try to make a profit. Although first released for Microsoft Windows and Macintosh in 2001, it was ported to the Nintendo DS in 2005. It was followed by two expansion packs, Zoo Tycoon: Dinosaur Digs and Zoo Tycoon: Marine Mania, which were released in 2002, as well as a sequel, Zoo Tycoon 2, released in 2004.".
